awd_titl_txt: SHF:  Small:  Application Shrinking for Reducing Energy Consumption
awd_abstract_narration:
The management of energy consumption is a key driver in the design of modern computing platforms, from mobile devices (where lower consumption leads to better battery lifetimes) to desktop and servers (where lower consumption leads to significant decreases in electricity costs and heat dissipation). However, despite numerous advances in low power design technologies, the power consumption of the IT industry remains significant and worse, is slated to grow in the coming years. The prospect of growing energy demands for computing systems has implications for the economy, the environment and for society in general. The broad goal of this research is to make it easier to reduce the energy consumption of computer systems, while still maintaining their functionality.

An emerging way to reduce energy consumption is to leverage heterogeneity in the choice of individual components to tradeoff power consumption versus performance. The key idea of such "Collaborative Heterogeneous" systems is to use low-power low-performance helper platforms in lieu of high-performance high-power parts whenever feasible, thus keeping the high-power subsystems shutdown to save energy. To unleash the full potential of Collaborate Heterogeneous systems, this research will develop techniques that can automatically generate shrunk versions of applications that are suitable for running on low-power resource-constrained helper platforms. This research will lead to new techniques for application shrinkage, to better tools for measuring energy savings, and to an empirical evaluation of the energy savings made possible by Collaborative Heterogeneous systems.  The techniques developed in this research will also be useful for generating "shrunk" versions of applications for use in heterogeneous multi-core Architectures and for running on portable energy-constrained devices like SmartPhones.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated ways of making systems more energy efficient through the use of software techniques.

First, the project developed techniques for finding energy problems in the software running on phones. In particular, there is a particular kind of error in phone software in which the software unintentionally leaves parts of the phone turned on, for example the wireless radio used for Internet connections. This is the equivalent of forgetting the lights on at home, except that it's very hard to find these kinds of bugs, because they can drain the battery without the user of the phone noticing where the energy is going (for example, a user does not realize when the wireless radio on their phone is turned on). For example, there was a notorious bug in the Facebook app around 2010 that drained the battery very quickly for exactly this reason. This error was eventually fixed, bur only after the faulty software was released and many users suffered the consequences of the battery drainage. The project funded under this award developed techniques that will help developers like Facebook and other software manufacturors find these kinds of errors before the software is released, thus avoiding users from being exposed to such accidental battery drainage.

Second, the project funded under this award developed software techniques for efficiently managing Heat, Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) systems in a building. In particular, the project developed a comprehensivee system called BuildingDepot that can keep track of many kinds of information about a building using a variety of sensors, and then can make decisions about how to tune the HVAC system to be more energy efficient. The project has shown that this kind of data- and sensor-driven approach to controlling HVAC systems can lead to anywhere between 12% and 40% energy savings, while at the same time providing occupants of the building with more control over their HVAC settings.
